title: Toll signs along I-66 weren’t working for a bit Tuesday morning
text:
A recent view of the I-66 tolls inside the Beltway in Northern Virginia. (Washington Post photo/Washington Post photo)

The signs for tolls along Interstate 66 in Virginia weren’t working properly for about an hour Tuesday morning due to a technical issue, officials said, making it the second day in a row the signs have had troubles.

On Tuesday morning, the signs along the highway inside the Beltway did not come on at 5:30 a.m. as they are supposed to, according to Ellen Kamilakis, a spokeswoman for Virginia’s Department of Transportation. They came on briefly for about 10 minutes around 6 a.m. but then went off. They came back on around 7:15 a.m., she said.

Kamilakis said drivers wouldn’t be charged for the time the signs were out and that a 12-minute grace period is being allowed for those who may have been on the road when the toll signs were out.

Officials said technical experts are looking into the problem.

On Monday, there was another technical problem with the toll signs as well.

The tolls run for 10 miles along a stretch of I-66 between the Capital Beltway and the District and charge solo drivers during peak travel times. Motorcycles and vehicles with two or more people aren’t charged.

This story has been updated.
description: Officials said a network outage caused the signs for tolls along I-66 in Virginia to not work properly.
